Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation: Investigating the role of social responsibility on Veteran student retention

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Social responsibility is the way a career can positively impact society. It is one of the core ideals of all branches of the military and why many students choose to study engineering. The goal of this research is to determine the relationship between the principle of social responsibility in military service and veterans' pursuit of engineering degrees. Several programs exist to help veterans transition from service to civilian life, including support for higher education. Many veterans enter engineering degree programs; however, the dropout/dismissal rate of these students is significantly higher than other engineering students nationally. Unfortunately, research is lacking on how to understand and improve graduation rates of veteran students in engineering. Results of this study will allow researchers to design interventions for improving the number of veteran engineering student graduates nationwide. The veteran student population brings unique backgrounds and experiences that contribute to the national initiative of developing a diverse, globally competitive engineering workforce. Broader impacts of this research include: (1) diversifying pathways through engineering, (2) increasing veteran student success in engineering, (3) engaging a wide range of veteran participants, and (4) integrating mentoring between engineering and education faculty to build a foundation for future collaboration on engineering education proposals.

This project asks and answers the research question: What is the role of social responsibility in reducing veteran student attrition in engineering? The research approach is to create a survey using the Dillman Tailored Design method to identify social responsibility attitudes in veteran and first-year engineering students. An External Advisory Board comprised of veterans with engineering backgrounds is involved as an external expert review panel to provide baseline validity for the survey items. The results of the survey as well as interviews of faculty and a veteran student focus group are used to determine if concepts of social responsibility positively influence veteran student retention. The survey, based on an existing model to measure social responsibility in veteran students, is a novel approach to understanding veteran student attrition. The PIs expect the results of the survey to provide a framework and justification for other research questions and/or projects related to veteran student retention in engineering. Determining veteran student motivation in higher education is a fundamental advancement in veteran student retention across all colleges. Furthermore, as social responsibility is a motivator for underrepresented students, the PIs expect these research findings to directly impact student graduation rates across engineering with the potential to even further diversify pathways to engineering degrees. The PIs plan to disseminate research findings to engineering educators and military constituents through national engineering/veteran conferences, workshops, peer-reviewed publications, and magazines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project sought to better understand how military veteran students in engineering view social responsibility. Social responsibility is defined as the obligation an individual or organization has to act for the benefit of society. Engineering student perceptions of social responsibility have been broadly studied, and are established teaching principles that increase retention. Social responsibility is also an ideal promoted in all branches of the military. Notable resources have been invested in helping veterans’ transition to civilian lives and many veterans initially choose to pursue engineering degrees. Unfortunately, the drop out and dismissal rate of veterans is very high, significantly higher than traditional students, and most of this attrition happens in the first semester. Furthermore, social responsibility has been examined with first-year engineering students and was found to be positively related to retention, and yet, its applicability and relevancy to the veteran students remain unclear.  A sequential mixed-method approach was used in this study by modifying an established survey instrument together with qualitative interviewing for data collection to explore the perceptions of social responsibility among veteran engineering students. Survey data were also collected from first-year and senior engineering students.

First-year students served as the baseline for instrument validation purposes related to the modified survey. Both groups allowed some control on extraneous factors (e.g., demographics) that could potentially affect veteran students’ perceptions besides those associated with being a veteran. Factor analysis and Cronbach alpha were performed to measure validity and reliability. Correlational analysis was conducted to examine any group differences between traditional first-year, traditional senior, and veteran (all years) students regarding social responsibility. The findings revealed that veteran students in engineering in this study showed a high level of identification to social responsibility and there was no strong statistical evidence suggesting that they were drastically different from first-year engineering students concerning social responsibility. There was a statistical difference between first-year and senior student perceptions of social responsibility, which has similarly been identified by other researchers. Qualitative data supported the statistical results but further contextualized the veteran students’ understanding of social responsibility and their perceived connections between social responsibility and engineering. All these suggest that the current literature on social responsibility for first-year engineering students is applicable to veteran students. In particular, the first year in college can be extremely critical for the retention of veteran students for it is the time they need to experience a strong sense of social responsibility in the classrooms. Veteran students need to see the continuity and/or connection between in what they have done, are currently learning, and service to community, to develop their sense of belonging in engineering.

This project has many broader impacts. First, it sheds lights on diversifying pathways through engineering. The military veteran student population is more diverse than any other in engineering, regarding both demographics and life experiences which add value to the classroom and profession. The findings of this research have implications for practice and policy in engineering education to increase student retention. For instance, incorporating social responsibility in engineering curriculum is not only necessarily but also needs to done much earlier; specifically, the first semester. This research process allowed a wide range of stakeholders to participate – besides the faculty on the research team, a graduate and several undergraduate students worked on the project and learned research skills. Finally, this grant built capacities through cross-disciplinary mentoring between engineering and education faculty, which created a foundation for future collaboration on engineering education focused grant proposals. This was a specific objective of the Research Initiation in Engineering formation program and it was addressed through a very targeted mentoring program.
